section.name: Writing Documentation for Gforge
section.p:
The documentation for the GForge is written in the xdoc format. It is a simple markup language, based on xml.
xdoc has some big advantages over writing documents in other formats, like html, doc, etc:
simple to use: the markup language is very simple, with only a small number of tags. It is easy to learn
multiple output: .html, .pdf, .txt, .ps files can be easily generated from one source file
platform independent, language independent, application independent: xml documents are not dependent on specific platforms

section.name: Writing a xdoc
section.p:
All xdoc documents should start with the following header: Your name Document title and end with the following instructions: The xdoc can contain the following tags: Section definitions using the section tag Ordered lists and unordered lists using ol and ul code formatting using the source and code paragraph definitions using the p tag line breaks using the br tag text formatting using b and i tags You can also use html-style tables in your xdoc, this tables will be converted only to html (not to pdf). John Foo Gforge usage

Gforge has the following menu items:

  1. Project help
    Here you can obtain help for your Project!

section.name: How to generate pdf and html
section.p:
We are currently using maven to create the documentation.
the docs/xdocs folder contains all information/files needed to create the output formats. To create the pdf documentation, type
maven pdf
To create the html documentation, type:
maven
The documentation will be created in the target/docs subdirectory.
